poem:
Title: Akin to A Kaleidoscope 

Afrofuturism, bold as Basquiat's hand,
twisting, turning diaspora's dance,
thread of Butler's ink in spectral sand,
under Disney's audacious glance.

Elliott's rhythm in starlight spun,
new worlds from cultures deep and rich,
marrying tech with traditions won,
a resounding, vibrant pitch.

From Marvel's mask to resplendent dawn,
a future steeped in African song.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Iwájú review – Disney steps into a bold and brilliant future Afrofuturism emerged in the 1970s/80s as a way to express the African diaspora’s potential and present concerns. It used speculative technology, married to deeply rooted traditions, culture and aesthetics, to imagine a future founded in African ambition. It appears in the novels of Octavia Butler, the vivid canvases of Jean-Michel Basquiat and the music of Missy Elliott, but its most famous iteration is Marvel’s". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
